message_1: What is the age of a sample containing 10 grams of carbon-14 if it currently contains only 2.5 grams of carbon-14, and has a half-life of 5,700 years?
message_2:
To determine the age of the sample, we can use the half-life formula:

N = N0 * (1/2)^(t/T)

Where:
N = the final amount of carbon-14 (2.5 grams)
N0 = the initial amount of carbon-14 (10 grams)
t = the time elapsed (which we want to find)
T = the half-life of carbon-14 (5,700 years)

Rearranging the formula to solve for t:

t = T * (log(N/N0) / log(1/2))

Plugging in the values:

t = 5700 * (log(2.5/10) / log(1/2))
t ≈ 5700 * (log(0.25) / log(0.5))
t ≈ 5700 * (-2 / -1)
t ≈ 5700 * 2
t ≈ 11,400 years

The age of the sample containing 10 grams of carbon-14 is approximately 11,400 years.
